newsitem.title: UK: Quiet emerging market debt see Russian risk soften.
newsitem.headline: Quiet emerging market debt see Russian risk soften.

text.p: The emerging market debt market was subdued amid mild two-way trade on Friday after profit-taking on Thursday, dealers said.

The market was also cautious ahead of U.S. producer price data due later and consumer price figures out on Wednesday. "If the figures are benign, we might see it the market firm up again," a dealer said.
A Reuters poll forecast June PPI to remain unchanged from May levels at minus 0.3 percent.
Emerging market analysts said Russia was a bit softer. "Mutterings about Vnesh is the rumour in the market," one said.
Market talk was that there could be a delay in the Vnesheconombank (VEB) rescheduling of debt to the year-end from around October.
Recently Vneshekonombank chairman Andrei Kostin said Russia expected to close agreement with the London Club of commercial bank creditors in the autumn.
"The Vnesh cash bond is probably the hardest hit."
At 1115 GMT, Russian VN US$ was bid at
Russian Minfin 3 was bid at 90.75, Minfin 4 at 68.50, Minfin 5 at 50.75, Minfin 6 at 56.625 and Minfin 7 at 44.25.
Brazilian Cs bonds were trading little changed from Thursday at around 83.50 and the country's global bond due 2027 at 99.50.
They said Argentina could be boosted by the 750 billion lire 10-year bond launched Friday to yield 156 basis points over the Italian swap rate.

"Any new money that Argentina raises with long duration on it serves to take Argentina away from the treadmill of short-term debt service," a dealer said. -- Hayley Pienaar, London Newsroom +44 171 542 7718
